As musing beside the clear stream</br>To Twick'nham's gay village ally'd,</br>Of Nancy I sung, and my theme</br>Kept pace and complain'd with the tide.
That murmur'd at loss of its POPE—</br>I mourn'd for the loss of my FAIR,</br>As each was like without hope</br>To meet with a jewel so rare.
Adieu ye sweet meadows and lawns!</br>No more on your paths shall I stray—</br>Or like the brisk lambkins and fawns,</br>So blithesomely speed the long day!
For Nancy (the cruellest maid!)</br>Hath left me alone to despair!</br>Nor heeds the soft things I have said—</br>Nay sworn to so oft in her ear.
O fool that I am to complain!—</br>Fly, Love!  quickly fly from my breast!—</br>Too long have I worn the slave's chain—</br>Too long been a stranger to rest!
Since Nancy will not lend an ear,</br>A nymph that's more kind I'll attend;</br>But nought of Love' tale shall she hear—</br>I'll promise to be her firm Friend.
Methinks I see Venus the gay—</br>The little rogue Cupid beside,</br>Directing an arrow this way,</br>And, smiling, my maxim deride.
But Venus may boast of her pow'r,</br>And Cupid contemptuously smile—</br>In Friendship I'll spend ev'ry hour—</br>No longer shall Love me beguile.
On Friendship grave Reason attends—</br>It warms as it grows, and takes root;</br>And gradually rip'ning, ascends—</br>Producing the wholesomest fruit.</br>
